ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I understand much better the complex history of Russia, both in terms of continuity and discontinuity.
This course did a good job of engaging with both primary and secondary sources and critically engaging with them. It taught me a lot about premodern Russia and the culture of the slavic states.
I developed knowledge of Russian history before 1801.
I learned so incredibly much about Russia and even Finland, Sweden, and Poland. If you really liked Timothy Synder's classes, you will enjoy this class in conjunction with Eastern Europe to 1914.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I would be happy if the readings for this course were entirely primary sources. Paul Bushkovitch gives great review of secondary material in his lectures, and the class discussions would be much facilitated by primary source readings, such as some of the fascinating ones we did cover.

This course did a good job of engaging with a wide range of material. Unfortunately this meant that some material was glossed over. However, the material we did focus on was interesting and the course made us engage with the material in instructive ways.
The course could be improved by providing students with more specification as to the format of and content covered by examinations.

I really liked that this was a comparatively small lecture class, making it more of a seminar. Class was divided into two halfs, there was lecture and then reading discussion. Also, Professor Bushkovitch's exams are notoriously straightforward. "Either you know it or you don't."

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to anyone who plans to speak about, write about, or do anything apropos of Russia anytime in their life.
Yes, but only if the student has a vigorous interest in Russian history.

I would completely recommend this class to another student. It is easier than Timothy Snyder's classes, but just as interesting and more comprehensible. You will learn a lot and it was a small-ish class. Make sure you speak during class so you actually get something out of the discussions!
